question: ... Well, I mean it. I'm serious -- I do. You promise and promise, and then you change your mind, just like that.
answer: ... Uh-huh.

question: You wait 'til you ask me for something. Just wait. See if you get it.
answer: Toby, hush. Let me just... So concentrated on her driving she doesn't even finish her sentence, she nurses the car upward. Finally the car crests the hill and starts down. Caroline sighs with relief. She turns to Toby with a smile. What'd you say?

question: I said -- for the twentieth time -- if a person promises somebody something, they can't just turn around and take it back.
answer: Oh, honey, Jesus. Don't start with that again.

question: Why not?
answer: Because I'm the mother, and I get to tell you what to do every minute of your life 'til you're eighteen. Seriously, we've got no money. I can't buy you the moccasins.

question: I bet if you'd promised Roy some moccasins he'd of got 'em.
answer: No talk about Roy, okay? And ditto the moccasins. We, can't, afford, them.

question: Yeah, but you did promise...
answer: Sue me. Take me to court. Oh, Toby, I know you're disappointed, but...

question: Jack. Call me Jack.
answer: You're going to drive me to an early grave

question: Seriously. If a person can't get a stinking miserable pair of moccasins, at least he ought to be able to choose his own name... ... and I wanna be called Jack!
answer: Fine. And you can call me... ... Jeanette. Jeanette Marie.

question: Oh, you're so stupid sometimes,
answer: Goddamn thing. Oh, that poor man. There is a pause. Then Toby speaks:

question: I hope to hell this isn't some kind of omen. Caroline turns to Toby, her face worried. Then she sees the look in Toby's eyes -- he's ragging her. She grins and gives his shoulder a light, affectionate shove. How's this thing work, anyway?
answer: It makes a black light that, uh, causes uranium traces to glow.

question: And we just walk along the street and find this glowing uranium?
answer: Well, it was everywhere in Moab, they say -- just like gold in the gold-rush days.

question: But we were too late in Moab, and that guy at the office said nobody'd found any uranium in Salt Lake City.
answer: Well, that means we'll have the place pretty much to ourselves, huh? Honey, this could be a big break for us. If this works out, oh, just think Ask me how far we are from Salt Lake City. Toby is instantly awake, excited. Caroline points to a small highway sign and both she and Toby yell out. CAROLINE/TOBY Forty-seven miles to go! If I could have one wish right now -- only one wish -- you know what I'd like? I'd like to burn this damn Nash Ambassador to a crisp. I'm serious. I hate it. I hate the factory that produced it, and I hate the man who invented it.

question: It almost makes me want to see Roy -- he was the only one could make the thing stop overheating. My God, he was boring. Boring and mean
answer: I'd like to burn you to the ground. Let's go get rich in Salt Lake City!

question: I'd like to burn you to the ground. Let's go get rich in Salt Lake City!
answer: You're pulling my leg, right?

question: No, I came here to look for uranium.
answer: My God, lady. If you're looking for uranium, why didn't you go to Moab?

question: We went there, but everybody'd beaten us there. We were too late.
answer: So you came here just on the chance you'd find uranium? Listen, you mind me saying something to you might sound rude? Lady, you got more courage than you got common sense.

question: Seriously. It needs points, and it overheats constantly, but you can have it if you want it, because my hand to God, I can't look at it one more minute.
answer: Well, sure...

question: Get the bags out. Get the owner's slip out of the glove compartment. We're rid of this son-of-a-bitch pink and white albatross. You don't mind taking a car with a big dent in the passenger door?
answer: Hell, no. There's no dent there... Caroline draws back her leg and delivers a terrific, flat-footed kick to the door, leaving a dent the size of a dish-pan.

question: Oh, yes there is! Toby hands the Woman the owner's slip, Caroline gives her the keys.
answer: ... you really just giving me this car?

question: It's done. It's yours. You got yourself a Nash Ambassador! Let's go! Both of them pick up two bags apiece -- all they have in the world -- and off they go, feeling good. ... find ourselves a cheap room someplace, we'll get you into school, I'll brush up on my typing and get a job, and things'll start looking up. I feel it
answer: Yeah, and like Dad used to say, 'We may be broke, but we're never poor.' And later, if we get a house with a big yard, I could get a collie, you know? One like Lad or Grey Dawn. And someday maybe a palomino. And I'm going to try harder in school, too... The two of them walk on -- a bit foolish, but, in an odd way, brave as hell. She works. She's working. Silent, the man continues to hold out the telephone to Toby. Finally he takes it and dials. It wasn't me broke their stupid windows.

question: Liar.
answer: Gee, thanks a lot, Mom -- believe them instead of me.

question: If you care anything about me at all, you'll shut up.
answer: Yeah, well if you'd stayed married to Dad none of this would've ever happened.

question: Look, don't you put that on my back My head is killing me. Toby heads for his room. What time is it?
answer: Seven. Almost.

question: Why didn't you wake me?
answer: I started dinner. The potatoes are frying, and I'm heating up the hot dogs. Caroline sees that he's trying to make it up to her, and pats the bed for him to sit down next to her. He moves to sit beside her.

question: Hold your mother's hand.
answer: I'm sorry.

question: I know you are, honey. Ah, well -- it wasn't fire, and nobody bled, so I guess we're okay. The TELEPHONE RINGS and she answers it. When she hears the VOICE on the other end she once again touches her right cheekbone with a finger -- the spot where the bruise had been. She sags back against a wall. Yes... Yes... Yes, I know... You're right... All right, yes... in an hour, then. Caroline hangs up.
answer: Who was that? She closes her eyes. Who was that? Caroline laughs aloud, then slides down the wall until she's on the floor still laughing.

question: We've got a guest for dinner
answer: ... I found me a room, but it's clear the hell and gone 'cross town. And I think I got a job lined up doin' tune-ups in a Texaco station. How you like it at Winstead's?

question: How do you know where I work?
answer: I been here almost a week.

question: You followed me around? For a week? Watching? Roy doesn't answer. He just wiggles his eyebrows like Groucho Marx. And how did you ever find me? Again, Roy does the Groucho Marx. He turns to Toby.
answer: You like the rifle, Toby? 'Jack,' I mean.

question: It's the best present I ever got. I just love it. I'm going to pretend I'm shooting.
answer: Don't point that thing at anybody or I won't teach you to shoot.

question: It's not loaded!
answer: You heard me

question: It's got no bullets, for God's sake.
answer: Don't make me speak to you again.

question: I'll point it at the sky, then. Caroline sighs. Toby opens a screenless window and points the gun up into the night sky, pretending to fire it over and over. Caroline starts to clear the table. Roy jumps up to help her.
answer: Don't. Toby's still up. Roy leans back, smiling, and eyes Caroline.

question: Hello. The Woman stops to take a breather, lights a cigarette, pokes her companion. Over there. I won't be here long, though, 'cause my dad's coming to get me. Yeah. I'm gonna live on his ranch in Phoenix. The "Lazy B," it's called. It is. I've got a palomino horse and a collie, and Dad lets us go on hunts all by ourselves. He gave me this Winchester .22, and last year I shot a mountain lion with it. And Lad -- that's my dog -- found a nest of rattlesnakes one time, and killed all twelve of them... The two Women exchange a glance. It's obvious the boy is lying. What're you doing home so -- We going someplace?
answer: We sure are.

question: Where?
answer: I don't know. Got any suggestions?

question: Phoenix.
answer: Good. I was thinking of Phoenix or Seattle -- lots of opportunities in both those places.

question: What about your fabulous boyfriends? What about the fabulous, boring Roy? Is he coming, too?
answer: Not if I can help it. I looked out the window at work today, and he was parked across the street, watching.

question: Roy's so uncool. So boring.
answer: You liked him well enough last night. 'Oh, Roy, I just love my rifle so much! It's the bestest present ever!'

question: Oh, shut up. But he's smiling, completely unbothered. Suddenly Caroline laughs, stands up, and begins to close the suitcases. Toby laughs, too. Now? We're going now? What about all the food?
answer: Leave it.

question: Even the canned stuff?
answer: Leave it! They grab the four heavy suitcases and head out the door. Both of them are laughing.

question: Well, ask him when the next one to Phoenix is.
answer: What about Seattle? ... I've always had a good head for figures, and if I could get my C.P.A. license, I believe we could make a real go of it in Seattle. I'll advertise for roommates, and I bet we find us a real cute house to rent.

question: If there's a big yard, can I get a collie?
answer: Sure. Oh, honey, I feel a wind at my back

question: Yeah -- like heaven on a June day. The DOORS of the bus close. WHOOSH! The bus begins to move. Caroline and Toby's faces are at the window
answer: ... and if you cut school again I'll just wear you out -- do you hear me? I'm tired of it!

question: Yeah, yeah... Toby exits the house. But, Jesus, what a new Toby Hey, Terry.
answer: Hey, Jack. What'd your mom say about skipping school today?

question: Who listens?
answer: You go over to Wanda's house last night? You make out good? How good?

question: I fucked her 'til her nose bled.
answer: Sure you did! Oh, Wolff, you're rich. Excuse me, but does your face hurt? 'Cause it's killing me. With that piece of high wit, they're out of the room.

question: Oh, Lois. Oh, baby, come here -- I got six hot inches just waiting for you.
answer: Man, look at her! Look at that body-y-y-y.

question: It does pick up the green, doesn't it?
answer: And you say he's getting serious already?

question: Yes, I think. He keeps talking about marriage, keeps saying he wants to meet Toby.
answer: Well, that's it -- three dates and you got 'im good.

question: Really? I can shoot my Winchester? Great! I bet I could be the one to get the turkey.
answer: Well, amazing I want you to be polite to Dwight this weekend.

question: Okay.
answer: I mean it, now.

question: I said 'Okay,' didn't I?
answer: Hey, c'mon, maybe the weekend'll be fun... maybe Concrete will be pretty.

question: Oh, Concrete, my favorite town. Welcome to beautiful Concrete!
answer: And stop that.

question: Stop what?
answer: Sometimes I could kill you as free as I could eat a bite.

question: Ditto. A car stops and through a window, we see Dwight. Caroline turns to Toby.
answer: Please be nice. Toby stops the buck-toothed thing and speaks normally.

question: It's a few miles downriver.
answer: Forty miles.

question: Come off it -- it's not that far.
answer: Yeah, I clocked it

question: 'Turkey shoot' is just a figure of speech.
answer: There's no real turkey?

question: No, it's just regulation paper targets. It's a test of skill. And, Jack, I just found out yesterday that they won't let kids shoot.
answer: But you said I could!

question: Wolff. Caroline Wolff.
answer: You mean you want to enter? I think it's against the rules.

question: Well, that sign says this is an N.R.A. club, and I'm a dues-paying N.R.A. member. That gives me the right to participate in the activities of other chapters.
answer: You'll be the only woman shooting. Caroline just smiles. The Man shrugs, takes her money and writes down her name. That second-place trophy ain't bad, honey.

question: So what do you think?
answer: They're okay. What's that bald spot on Pearl's head? Ugh.

question: Some sort of infection.
answer: Norma's nice.

question: They're all nice, but Dwight keeps rushing me, keeps talking about marriage. And I don't really want to get married -- not now anyway.
answer: That's fine with me. I wish you would've stayed married to Dad.

question: Oh, don't wish Duke back on me. God.
answer: That woman he married? Is she really rich?

question: Like King Midas. Okay, look, we'll go back to Seattle and see how things go. I've been thinking about taking a course in stenotyping. A court reporter's pay is real high. Kathy got engaged, so either I find us another roommate or I've got to make some more money. And this stenotyping thing sounds just right. This could turn out good, honey.
answer: I mean I blew it off, man -- I blew his fuckin' turkey's head off. Terry Silver takes a long slow drag on his cigarette. The other boys glance at each other

question: I mean I blew it off, man -- I blew his fuckin' turkey's head off. Terry Silver takes a long slow drag on his cigarette. The other boys glance at each other
answer: With a .22.

question: Fuckin' A. Winchester .22. Pump.
answer: Wolff, you are so full of shit.

question: Don't believe me -- see if I care.
answer: All a .22 bullet would do is make a hole in his head. Toby takes a drag on his cigarette.

question: One bullet, maybe.
answer: Oh. Oh, I see -- you hit the turkey more than once. While he was flying. In the head.

question: What did he do?
answer: He violated the school property and flouted the law.

question: Can you say that in English?
answer: He wrote obscene words on the wall.

question: Did you do it? He didn't do it.
answer: He wrote obscene words on the wall.

question: What obscene words?
answer: 'Fuck you.'

question: That's one obscene word. Mr. Shippy looks stymied. There is a pause.
answer: Look, Mrs. Wolff, Jack's teachers, like him but they think he's fallen in with the wrong kind of friends. Is that nicotine stain on your fingers? I hope not. Let me tell you a story After that, every day I saved the exact amount of money I would've spent on cigarettes. In three years, I put it all together, and you know what I bought? I bought myself... ... a Nash Ambassador. Caroline gives a bark of laughter. She brings out a handkerchief and coughs, as if she has a cold. Mr. Shippy looks puzzled. Well, back to the point

question: So what shall we do?
answer: What do you mean?

question: Ever since Duke and I got divorced, you're a different boy. I know he never calls you and I could kill him for it -- but that's how Duke is. And Gregory's in Princeton now, so I guess... So what shall we do? Because this isn't working. We barely have enough money, Kathy's moving out, and on top of it all, you've gone wild. You lie...
answer: No I don'...

question: Yes, you do. You steal from Marian's purse -- I just can't handle you anymore, and it scares me. I don't know what to do. So, you tell me what to do.
answer: I can be better. I will be. And I hate the way I am anymore! I don't know why I do it! What about that stenotyping thing you were gonna do? With peculiar intensity, Caroline speaks in a soft, odd voice:

question: It won't happen. It won't happen. It won't happen. Things aren't going to turn out well, things aren't going to start looking up, and it's never going to be like heaven on a June day. There is no uranium. There is no stenotyping. There is no C.P.A. license. There isn't... She stands for a few moments as if listening for a far-off sound. ... I talked to Dwight
answer: What are you going to do, just give me away to him?

question: If you two can get along, if it works out, then I guess he and I might get married. I can't think of anything else to do. But first I want your approval. Again the two stare at each other.
answer: All right. Caroline nods, turns away.

question: I put in both your sweaters. You wear them now, the nights are so chilly up there.
answer: Okay. I will.

question: You don't have to go if you don't want to, honey.
answer: No, it's okay. I'll go. O.S. we hear a KNOCKING and Dwight's cheery voice.

question: No, it's okay. I'll go. O.S. we hear a KNOCKING and Dwight's cheery voice.
answer: Here I am, you lucky people!

question: Hey, look
answer: Go get it -- the pelt's worth fifty bucks, minimum.

question: That thing's probably got rabies...
answer: Get it!

question: I'm a little sick to my stomach.
answer: Sick to your stomach? A hotshot like you?

question: I'm not a hotshot.
answer: That's what I hear. I hear you're a real hotshot. Come and go where you please, do what you please. Isn't that right? Yeah, regular man about town. Performer, too. That right, Jack? You a performer?

question: No, sir.
answer: That's a goddamned lie. Dwight keeps glancing from the road to Toby, and back again. If there's one thing I can't stomach, it's a liar.

question: I'm not a liar.
answer: Sure you are. You or Marian. Is Marian a liar? She says you're quite the little performer. Is that a lie? You tell me that's a lie and we'll drive back to Seattle so you can call her a liar to her face. You want me to do that?

question: No.
answer: Then you must be the one's a liar, right? And you're a performer?

question: I guess.
answer: You guess? You guess? Let's see your act. Go on. Do your act. I'm waiting.

question: I can't.
answer: Sure you can.

question: No, sir.
answer: Do me. I hear you do me. Again Toby shakes his head, and then gasps as the CAR SKIDS hideously close to the cliff's edge. Dwight is oblivious to the danger. Yeah, I hear you're good at doing me. Here. Do me with the lighter. Go on. Take it. Dwight holds out the velvet-covered Zippo, driving with one hand, and the car is all over the road. Dwight puts the lighter back into his pocket. The car slows a bit. Hotshot. You pull that hotshot stuff around me and I'll break every bone in your body. You understand me? You're in for a change, mister. You got that? Huh? You got that good? You're in for a whole 'nother ballgame. Skipper, go get that washtub out back, and Pearl, bring the hose around and fill it up. Hotshot and me hit a beaver. We'll salt him down. Skipper and Pearl move out on the run. Dwight slits the beaver from throat to testicles, guts it, then pulls the skin off. I know you think you're better than me. Caroline told me all about your rich daddy and your prep-school brother, but your fancy days are over

question: I'm getting one for me, too. Don't believe in doing anything halfway. If you're serious about the Scouts... ... then I want you to do it right. We'll do it right together. Dwight takes out a magazine entitled Boy's Life. He hands it to Toby. I got you a subscription to this. I'll take the price out of your paper route money.
answer: Boy's Life?

question: It's the official Scout magazine. Tells about what it means to be a Scout, what kind of boy you need to be, and, oh, about merit badges and stuff like that. Toby opens the book at random, reads from it.
answer: 'Suggested good turns a Scout can do

question: Hell, yes, you could. You're a bright kid. I want this Scout thing done right, okay? Toby nods, enthusiastic, happy.
answer: I'm not going.

question: The hell you say.
answer: I'm not. Cut down Skipper's old stuff, and he's twice as big as me -- I'm gonna stay home.

question: You're gonna shit and fall back in it -- that's all you're gonna do. Now get out here. Shut your pie-hole. You look fine.
answer: I look like an idiot.

question: You act like an idiot, you look fine.
answer: You said you'd get me a new uniform.

question: I said I'd try to get you a new uniform. Beside, this one is new -- new to you.
answer: But look at the sleeves and how it hangs down between my legs!

question: Oh piss and moan -- all you can do is piss and moan.
answer: Yeah, piss and moan -- I notice you're all jazzed up in new stuff.

question: They didn't have second-hand uniforms in my size.
answer: Oh, yeah, pull the other leg, it's got bells on it! Toby throws himself down on the sofa.

question: And what're you gonna tell Caroline this weekend? You gonna say you wouldn't join the Scouts because... him didn't wike his widdle uniform? Dwight picks up the copy of Boy's Life and thumbs through it, He reads: 'No boy given over to dissipation or negativity can stand the gaff. He quickly tires and gives up. He is the type who usually lacks courage at the crucial moment. He cannot take punishment and come back smiling.' Dwight looks at Toby expectantly. Toby hesitates, then gives up.
answer: All right, but this stinks. Toby walks outside. Dwight follows.

question: Oh, I missed you!
answer: Me, too.

question: You look good. How are you?
answer: I'm okay. I'm fine.

question: I said to hell with the budget and bought a roast. I made dumplings -- God, what's wrong with your hands?
answer: It's just juice from some chestnuts -- it'll wear off.

question: How is it in Concrete?
answer: It's fine.

question: School?
answer: School's school. My grades are okay.

question: You haven't been in any trouble? Good. How're you and Dwight?
answer: He made us all snowcream, like he said.

question: Stop that, honey.
answer: What?

question: Well, you've got your eyes out of focus. Look at me. Now, are things all right?
answer: I'm fine.

question: You swear? You act odd.
answer: No, I'm fine.

question: Well, good. I'd feel awful if it hadn't worked out. A pause. I told Dwight I'd marry him. In two weeks. I don't know what else to do. I mean, he's been helping me with the rent since Kathy left. And you need a father. I think it's the best thing all the way around -- what d'you think? There is a pause as they look at each other.
answer: I think it's the best thing.

question: I think it's the best thing, too. Caroline smiles, smooths his hair, then goes into the house. Toby continues to walk. Suddenly, he spins around and tears out toward the house. By God, he'll tell her just what's been going on. He bangs through the front door and up the stairs.
answer: Hungry. He makes another sign. Food. He makes another sign. Want. He makes another sign. Great mystery. He makes another sign. Father. He stares silently at himself in the mirror.

question: Hungry. He makes another sign. Food. He makes another sign. Want. He makes another sign. Great mystery. He makes another sign. Father. He stares silently at himself in the mirror.
answer: Now that's a song. Not all this Elvis Presley shit. Elvis sings about like I do brain surgery. He imitates Elvis -- moves his hips slightly and sings a few notes: '... uh-huh-huh, my blue suede shoes.' Dwight gives Toby a flash of his teeth and Toby smiles back. Let's get this place ready for Caroline. They begin painting. After only a few strokes, though, Toby looks doubtful.

question: It's so white.
answer: I got a good deal on this paint. It'll darken up when it dries. What? I like it. It looks clean.

question: Yeah, but it makes everything else look so dark. Dwight's face changes. He has an idea.
answer: Sort of stands out, doesn't it?

question: Oh! Oh, I'm so sorry... don't know what's the matter with me... you're right... it does look clean... But she can't stop laughing. Her laughter has just a tinge of hysteria.
answer: M-m-m. There's not a straight line on you -- everything's curved. Caroline draws him up to her, and they kiss. Then Dwight turns Caroline on her side, away from him, pre- paring to enter her. Caroline makes a small sound of protest, turning back toward him.

question: Oh, Dwight, not like that. Not this time -- not tonight.
answer: It's good this way.

question: But I want to see your face while we make love.
answer: Oh, no -- I just don't... uh... like that way.

question: You mean you don't like to make love face to face?
answer: No, I don't like it. I can't handle it -- I don't like to see the face.

question: You mean ever? But that's grotesque...
answer: Look, you can get it doggie-style or you can get it laying on your side -- those are your only choices. This is my house, and I get to say. Wherever McGinty sits is the head of the table, you know? Disgusted, Caroline turns back away from Dwight. He shifts down on the bed a few inches, again preparing to enter her.

question: So how's the bride?
answer: Don't.

question: The bride doesn't want to chat?
answer: Stop it.

question: Well, the bride is sure snotty this morning. Smiling, Toby waits for some response to his teasing, but there is none. She turns away and sits at the table. What's his name again? He sure walks like a girl. He smarted off to me the other day -- told me I was a bourgeois. Why?
answer: Oh, my, my -- look at all that yellow

question: Oh, shut up.
answer: Now that's what I like -- an insult with some originality. Did you just make that up? Just now? So clever.

question: Why don't you take a long walk off a short pier?
answer: Excuse me, but has anyone ever told you your breath would gag a maggot? Both of Toby's friends laugh.

question: Well, at least I'm not a great big sissy! Two things happen instantly
answer: GET UP! GET UP, YOU SON OF A BITCHING MAGGOT GAGGER! I'LL STOMP YOUR GUTS OUT! I'LL KILL YOU! Toby gets up, and again Arthur sails in with those wild roundhouse swings. Then Toby gets in a solid punch to Arthur's face that rocks the bigger boy back on his heels. Arthur grabs his head and roars like a wounded buffalo. Almost immediately Arthur's eye puffs and begins to swell shut. Snot streaming from both nostrils, still roaring, Arthur flies at Toby again. Toby closes with him, to hold those flailing arms still, and the two stagger around the street like drunken dancers. They separate, exchange a few blows, then grapple with each other again. Then Arthur hooks Toby's leg, trips him, and the two roll off the shoulder of the road and down an embankment. They hit the muddy bottom of the gully still hitting, flailing, kicking -- first Toby is on top, then Arthur, then Toby, then Arthur. By now they are panting, each breath is a heave, a gasp. Then, suddenly, Arthur gives out completely -- he falls on top of Toby, pressing him deeper into the mud. With his last bit of strength Toby throws the bigger boy off him and sits up, while PEPPER BARKS FURIOUSLY at him and threatens to nip his leg. Toby staggers to his feet and starts to climb the gully. He looks relieved -- at least it's over. No, it's not. From behind him he hears three words. Take it back. Take it back. Arthur's words are not angry anymore. Toby's worn out too...

question: Okay.
answer: Say it.

question: Okay. I take it back.
answer: No, say 'You're not a sissy.' Toby glances at Oscar and Jimmy. Their faces are gleeful but he doesn't care what the hell they think.

question: You're not a sissy. Arthur immediately turns and walks away, but Toby ignores them and walks away in the opposite direction, delivering his hated newspapers.
answer: I won't do it, you know. I won't be a referee between the two of you.

question: Who asked you?
answer: You both do. You do. Just by coming home like this you ask me to take your side when he raises hell. Well, the answer's 'No.' I'm going to make this marriage work. No fights.

question: Oh, the bride is calm. Who the hell cares? Caroline refuses to argue. She picks up a piece of material and holds it up to the window to see if her choice of color was a good one.
answer: ... seems like this place is so ugly. Seems like everywhere I look there's something... ugly.

question: Who won?
answer: Uh, well, uh... he's the one can't see out of one eye.

question: Hot damn! You actually gave little Lord Gayle a black eye?
answer: Well, it wasn't black yet.

question: But it was all puffed up? Then it was a shiner. How'd it start?
answer: I called him a sissy. Dwight hoots with laughter and slaps his leg.

question: Well, he sure's hell can't sue you for slander. That boy fights for the pink team. Did you make him cry?
answer: Well... he was just ready to. I called him a big-assed, squat- to-pee sissy. I'd have won bigger except he hit me when I wasn't looking.

question: You said you'd show me how to dry-gulch somebody.
answer: Okay. Now you can always kick somebody in the balls, but I like this one better Now that's dry-gulching. Hit 'em in the throat, but do it before they're expecting it. Now you try.

question: I'm afraid I'll hurt you.
answer: You won't.

question: But I might. Finally Toby gives a half-hearted "Hah!" and swings the side of his forearm toward Dwight's throat. Dwight catches the arm easily.
answer: Come onnn. You're not trying. Again Toby hesitates, again he says "Hah!" and gives a lukewarm swing at Dwight's throat. Well, don't go all shy and delicate on me -- you're as sissy as little Miss Arthur Gayle. Yeah -- I'll just call you 'Little Miss Jackie Wolff.' Ooh, my, yes -- Hello, Jackie. Toby's eyes flare up, then he lowers his head, biting his lip, sniffling a bit. Aw, Jesus Christ, if you're gonna --

question: ... but ask him again, why don't you? I hate it so much.
answer: I asked him a week ago, I asked him this morning -- he wants you to keep the paper route.

question: Then make him give me the money. It's mine, I earned it. It's $220.00 already.
answer: He won't. He says he'll keep it for when you really need it.

question: That's not fair. I ought to be able to have my own money. But it's mine.
answer: You remind me of a baby bird -- you know those frantic little things with their mouths wide open, wanting, wanting.

question: Well, at least ask him about my gym shoes again. I can practice barefoot but for games I gotta have shoes.
answer: I'm not a referee. I won't do it.

question: Oh, we know, we know
answer: Well, I'll tell you what the bride will do

question: Oh, I hate it here! I wish we could just get up and go.
answer: I don't have another 'get up and go' left in me! You understand? I'm telling you I've hit a god- damn wall. I can't run anymore. Now this whole thing isn't perfect for me, either... let me impress that on you real strong, okay? I don't wake up singing every morning. But I'm going to make this marriage work -- I won't join in any fights, you got that? I won't even raise my voice! Caroline points to the sink. See those two roses? He picked them for me on his way home last night.

question: Big deal.
answer: I'm trying to concentrate on the good stuff. Norma appears in the kitchen door, wearing her cap and gown. She strikes a pose.

question: I'm telling you I didn't.
answer: And I know damn well you did.

question: Well, you're wrong.
answer: About some things, yeah. Not about this. You're a goddam hog, and I proved it.

question: How do you know Skipper didn't eat it? Or Norma? Or Pearl?
answer: I told all three of them to stay away from this candy for twenty- four hours.

question: Well, how do you know I even ate any?
answer: I counted them. You hogged down eleven chocolate covered cherries since yesterday afternoon.

question: So what?
answer: So that makes you a hog. I just wanted to establish that fact, and now I have. Caroline and Skipper enter, carrying throw pillows and materials. Hey. Mr. Hotshot Hog and I've just been establishing some facts, and what we come up with is this

question: Oh, Dad! Skipper leaves the room. Caroline sits down, begins to try various materials as coverings for the pillows.
answer: Why don't you ever take up for me?

question: Why don't you ever help me straighten that boy out? Caroline doesn't even look up. She threads a needle and begins to sew. Whilst Dwight paces around the room. All he does is read or listen to records or sing. I'm so sick of that shit! And when he isn't singing, he's watching T.V. And don't say you don't 'cause when I come home I always put my hand on top of it to see if it's warm, and it always is. This is the news, kid -- I'm wise to you.
answer: Oh, big, big deal, who cares, and as long as we're passing out news here, I don't want to do my paper route anymore.

question: I bet you don't -- big lazy candy hog like you'd rather lay on his ass and read, wouldn't you? Let me tell you something
answer: Then give me the money I earn!

question: Hell, no. I'm putting that in the bank for you for when you really need it -- cuss me now, thank me later.
answer: Mom, won't you at least make him let me have the shoes for gym? How can I play basketball without gym shoes? I'm the only one who -- Toby stops suddenly. He looks at Dwight for a beat or two, and then speaks in a different tone: It's not the shoes, is it? Or the candy. It's me, isn't it? You just can't stand the fact of me. Dwight glances at Caroline, who still looks at her sewing.

question: I, well, no, it's not that -- I just want you to be well-behaved. Your rich daddy 'Duke' doesn't care anything about you, and so somebody's got to train you, and one of the things you've gotta be trained about is not to be a hog and eat everybody's candy like a -- Dwight stops short as Caroline says one word.
answer: Oh. Oh.

question: What's the matter, honey?
answer: Oh. OH-H-H-H! I. Will. Not. Referee.

question: Bastard. Swallow that.
answer: You like my dog?

question: Yeah, he's nice.
answer: Smart, too -- he can talk.

question: Sure -- I just about believe you.
answer: Hey, Pepper -- what's on a tree? As PEPPER BARKS TWICE: Bark! Way to go, Pepper -- pretty smart. Oh, I was wondering, Pepper -- I wanted to ask you something Rough! Yeah, I know what you mean.

question: That's dumb. A little funny, though. How come your dad never comes to meetings with you?
answer: I don't have a dad. Never did. I sprang full-blown from my mother's forehead. You want to walk home with me and Pepper?

question: Sure -- compared to a ride home with Dwight, it'll be like heaven on a June day.
answer: ... Tobias? Your real name is Tobias? Toby... Tobias... I like it -- it's very elegant. My real parents would probably have given me an elegant name, too. I say 'real parents' because I suspect I'm a foundling. Somebody royal -- or at least very, very beautiful had me and gave me to my poor but honest mother. Tell me more about you.

question: Every day of my life feels like a mile on the Bataan Death March.
answer: I knew I'd like you.

question: Why'd you point at me that day?
answer: Because you're an alien. You don't belong in Concrete any more than I do. This place would like to kill us because we're different.

question: Oh, come on, Arthur. That's a little dramatic.
answer: Think so? You know what chickens do if one chicken's born with a little difference? With a few black feathers on its head, say? They peck at the black spot 'til the chicken's dead -- they can't stand the fact that it's different. Now we're both different. Your difference is something other than... ... my difference... But we're both aliens here.

question: I don't exactly feel like an alien. I've got friends here.
answer: Yes, and they're fools. And you act like a fool when you're around them. A prediction

question: Yeah, and you'll wind up a recluse that everybody says likes to dress up in his mama's old clothes.
answer: Maybe, maybe, but no matter how many times I have to repeat

question: Burma-Shave! Arthur and Toby laugh. As they walk on, though, Toby's face is thoughtful. Whose dog is that on the porch?
answer: Yours.

question: Mine?
answer: You said you wanted a dog.

question: A collie, though. Not this one.
answer: Well, he's yours. You paid for him. Go get ready for Norma's play.

question: What d'you mean I paid for him? But Dwight doesn't answer. Toby waits, then shrugs and leaves the room. My Winchester's gone.
answer: This dog is pure-bred Weimaraner. A champion.

question: I don't want it.
answer: Well, you're purely out of luck, aren't you, 'cause that rifle's on its way to Seattle.

question: I want my rifle!
answer: Well, want in one hand and shit in the other -- see which gets full first.

question: But, Dwight, that Winchester was mine.
answer: And Champ's your dog. Jesus, I trade some old piece of crap for a valuable hunting dog, and all you can do is piss and moan.

question: I'm not pissing and moaning.
answer: The hell you aren't. You can just make your own deals from now on.

question: All right. Okay, Dwight. You stay here. Don't come inside. Toby nods. Caroline heads inside, loaded for bear. Get his rifle back.
answer: But that dog's a champion! Caroline calmly SMASHES another PLATE on the countertop.

question: Get his rifle back.
answer: Am I supposed to go clear to Seattle just to get...

question: Get his rifle back.
answer: Jesus Christ, woman, I don't even know the guy's last name. Caroline picks up a bowl. All right, all right. The guy's supposed to send the A.K.C. papers. When he sends 'em, I'll know his name and address, and I'll go get the god-damn rifle back. Jesus. Caroline exits leaving Dwight, Norma, and Pearl with their mouths open.

question: Well, I did it -- and the bride didn't even raise her voice 'Course, having seen that dog, I wouldn't suggest you hang by your thumbs 'til those papers come. I mean, that dog is ugly. Toby gives her a dirty look, but Caroline's smile makes Toby grin. That's nice -- I haven't seen a real smile out of you in a month.
answer: Oh, Mom, can't we leave here? I hate it so much. You don't like it either -- all you do is stick your head in a sewing machine night and day. Let's just leave and start over someplace else.

question: 'Start over.' Do you know how many times I've started over, sweetheart? I don't want to do it anymore. This is as far as I want to go. This place. I have to make this work somehow. We do. You're fourteen now -- you have to help me.
answer: But if...

question: But me no buts, honey. I told you
answer: If you say 'look for the good stuff,' I'm gonna get Dwight's 30/30 and shoot myself!

question: Seriously, though
answer: Great. Just great. What a life I got no rifle... I got no gym shoes...

question: Heh Hotshot! He looks up just in time to see a flashlight fly through the air toward him. He catches it. Dwight stands in the doorway. If you can tear yourself away from your pedicure, I want you to fetch me some of that paint from the attic. Dwight switches the room light off.
answer: Yeah.

question: Is now too soon.
answer: God! It's hard to explain.

question: Your mother said you were sick. Feeling better?
answer: Yeah, I am.

question: Good, good. Get some sleep, did you?
answer: Yeah, I slept about four hours.

question: Must've needed it. A pause: Oh, by the way, you didn't happen to hear a funny pinging noise in the engine, did you?
answer: What engine?

question: I was downtown with Champ a few minutes ago, and I met a guy who recognized him. Said he'd seen my dog this very morning. Told me an interesting story of how he and the dog happened to meet. What d'you think about that?
answer: I don't know what you -- Suddenly Dwight is across the floor and onto the bed. He straddles Toby and slaps him across the face with the left hand then the right, again and again. Toby holds a forearm protectively across his face. Dwight holds both Toby's hands with one of his and, slaps the boy's face again and again. Finally Toby manages to get his right hand loose. He slams his forearm across Dwight's throat. Dwight rears back, choking and gagging. Toby throws off the covers and tries to run. Still choking, Dwight grabs the back of Toby's hair and forces the boy's face down against the mattress.

question: Oh, honey, good news -- Truman's going to campaign for him. I gave twenty-five dollars to his campaign office today. I've been thinking I'd like to work... She is interrupted by Dwight's voice O.S.
answer: Here I am, you lucky people! Toby and Caroline exchange a glance. It speaks volumes. ... So the S.O.B. had been on my back for a week at work, okay? Sayin' I stole his wrench, an' poured oil all over his tools, as if! Anyway, he went just one step too far with old Dwight, okay? Spat on the floor as I walked by. I turned around and walked back to him, acting so dainty and humble and scared, you know, all innocent -- and the minute he took his eyes off me, BLAM, I dry gulched him! I shut his water off good! Never gave me another second's grief to this very day. There is a pause. One more story. Nobody has much of a reaction.

question: I heard Kennedy on the news again tonight -- I don't know
answer: Kennedy -- the senator from Rome.

question: He gives me hope.
answer: I know what he gives you, and it sure as hell isn't hope.

question: It's true he is attractive! And it may just be those white teeth that I respond to. But I don't think so. I'm going to work for his campaign.
answer: No. Too many Republicans in this town. They hear my wife's working for the Democrats, they'll take their cars someplace else to be fixed. Bad idea. No.

question: Oh, Rickyyy! Oh, Ricky-y-y! Please let me come down and work at the club!
answer: What the hell are you doing?

question: You didn't pick this up yesterday -- congratulations, you got nothing higher than a C.
answer: Shut up. He signs the grade card, saying, "Presto."

question: You're gonna get caught some day. You act more like those morons you hang around with every day. Aghhh! I'm psycho! I'm retarded!
answer: He hears you do that, you're dead. Hey, lemme copy your math homework.

question: No, but I'll show you how to work the problems.
answer: I tell you I'm thirsty, you offer me a sandwich thank you and fuck you.

question: Oh, Jack.
answer: Oh, Jaaack!

question: I take it back you don't act like Psycho, you act like Dwight.
answer: I know it. He's winning. I do act like him. I feel like him sometimes. I've gotta get out of this place or I'm a dead one.

question: I know, but you've said that for two years.
answer: I mean it. I may go live with my brother Gregory in Princeton.

question: You mean the brother Gregory in Princeton who never calls you? That brother Gregory?
answer: He wrote me.

question: And he asked you to live with him?
answer: No. But I'm going. Or maybe I could go to a prep school like Gregory did. Like my dad did.

question: What about your grades? And what would you use for money?
answer: I don't know. Dwight owes me over twelve hundred bucks! If I hadn't let him keep my paper route money, I'd be okay.

question: If the dog hadn't stopped to pee, he'd have caught the rabbit. Suddenly Toby is angry. He stands up, moves to another seat.
answer: I think Dwight was right about you I think you fight for the pink team. Toby falls into another seat, then, pulls his head back and bangs it against the window. Then does it again, harder.

question: I know that, Psycho. That's my point
answer: What is it?

question: I called Gregory at Princeton. He's sending me applications for prep schools. I need you to take me to Seattle to take some entrance exams.
answer: Would a prep school take you with, uh, your school record?

question: I've got to get out of here, Mom. I've got to. I've got to get away.
answer: When are the tests?

question: Saturday.
answer: You'll be there.

question: He won't let you have the Buick.
answer: You'll be there! How was it?

question: Hard. I think I did okay. I'll know Monday.
answer: Take that trash out for me, honey. Toby grabs the trash and exits.

question: Hey, I thought I was helping him -- thought I'd save him some trouble 'cause he's got no chance of getting into some fancy prep school.
answer: You've always got your nose pressed up against the bake shop window, don't you, Dwight?

question: What?
answer: You feel like everybody else is inside, and you're stuck on the outside. It turns you mean. It turns you ugly. And one day do you hear me, Dwight? One day all that ugliness is going to snap back and hit you in the face.

question: I won't do it.
answer: But why? You work right in the office -- nobody'll ever know.

question: I'm surprised you'd want help from anybody who fights for the pink team.
answer: I'm asking you to help me, man. I got word yesterday that I did really well on those tests -- but that's not enough. I've got to cheat and lie -- but I don't care

question: No. Why should you get to be the one? Why not me?
answer: You could leave too, you know.

question: Come help me stuff envelopes.
answer: I'll do some this afternoon.

question: No, I need to take them with me.
answer: I'll be in in a minute. Let me finish this article.

question: Hello? All right. Tomorrow, then. Goodbye. Toby hangs up, turns to Caroline, quietly: It's Hill School -- the last one I applied to. They haven't accepted me, but they're sending somebody up to interview me. Caroline upsets the puzzle getting up to hug Toby. ... Yeah, I enjoy my classes, especially the ones that are advanced, but I've been feeling a little restless lately. It's hard to explain.
answer: Well, you're probably bored. Not being challenged. Your application was very good, Toby, but we have many boys who want to go to Hill. Not everybody is comfortable at a prep school.

question: I think I would be. My father and brother went to prep schools.
answer: Is that right? Where?

question: Deerfield and Choate. Mr. Howard is impressed.
answer: I see. Well, maybe you'd like it. Hill was difficult for me, though -- classes were hard, and the boys seemed cold -- interested in money and social position. And I hated those snowy Pennsylvania winters! But then in my last year, something changed. The guys in my class grew close, so close that I still think of them as a second family.

question: Hey, leopard. I say, 'Hey, leopard.' I know you, leopard -- I can see those spots you can't change. Thinks he can go to some fancy prep school and fool everybody. Not a chance. I know a thing or two about a thing or two. Toby won't rise to the bait, and Dwight falls silent, he, looks around and sees the jar of mustard on top of the trash. Who threw that away?
answer: I did.

question: Why?
answer: Because it was empty.

question: That money is gone with the wind. That's right. I spent it as you made it. It's gone. Poof. Toby starts for Dwight again. Caroline grabs him, saying, "No. No. No," over and over, literally dragging Toby away from Dwight. Caroline looks at Dwight.
answer: It's not so much that you're disappointing -- it's that you're consistently disappointing.

question: Oh, fancy, fancy talk -- fancy talk for a whore. I know a thing or two about a thing or two. I got friends in this town that tell me things, and I found out some man down at that campaign headquarters found you a job in Washington, D.C. Gonna run off with him, aren't you, Miss Whore?
answer: He's just a friend.

question: I'm leaving, Mom. You can leave, too. You don't have to stay here.
answer: I don't, do I?

question: No, you don't.
answer: I could leave with you, couldn't I?

question: My God... the lightness.
answer: What about me?

question: I'm leaving, too.
answer: No.

question: Oh, Dwight, why do you want me to stay? You don't even like me, not really.
answer: You're not leaving!

question: Look again, Dwight -- I'm already gone.
answer: ... you two've always sided in against me, always thought you were better than me. I tried. I did the best I could. What about me? Am I supposed to just crawl off in a ditch someplace and die? I've always been the nigger. Everybody's nigger. Ever since I was little. Caroline and Toby are at the door, run across the yard and down the street. Dwight stands in the doorway, yelling: What about me? When is it ever Dwight's turn for some consideration? What about me? I'll tell you one thing -- you'll remember me!
